description: Custom code is a powerful feature in Wynem that allows advanced users to write and execute custom JavaScript code directly in Discord. This gives you complete control over what happens when certain triggers occur, such as running a custom command or when an auto-response is triggered.

description.text: Where can custom code be used?

description: Custom code can be used in several places throughout Wynem:

rows: Run JavaScript code directly in Discord for any purpose
Write code that executes when users run your custom command
Write code that executes when messages trigger your auto-response

description: For more information about these features, see the Custom Commands and Auto-responses feature pages.

The <command:eval|eval> command allows you to run JavaScript code directly in Discord. This command uses the exact same environment as custom commands and auto-responses, giving you access to all the same functions and variables.
You can use eval for whatever you want, but it's particularly good for testing code before using it in custom commands or auto-responses.
To see what functions and variables are available in the environment, run `Object.keys(globalThis)` in the eval command.
Your custom code has access to several important variables and objects:

rows: The Discord message object that triggered the code
The Discord user object who triggered the code
The Discord guild member object who triggered the code (null in DMs)
The Discord server/guild object where the code is running (null in DMs)
The Discord channel object where the code is running
Array of arguments provided by the user (custom commands only)
Bot client information including prefix, stats, emotes, and colours

description: There are multiple ways to return or output values from your code:

rows: Use a return statement to explicitly return a value
Use console.log() to output debugging information
If the last line is an expression, it will automatically be returned

description: Your custom code can interact with Discord through various API actions:

tabs.name: Messages
content: The `sendMessage()` function is the primary way to send messages from your custom code.

tabs.name: Text Messages
content: Send simple text messages:
```sendMessage("Hello world!")```
```sendMessage(`Hello ${user.username}!`)```
**Note:** For simple text output, you can also just return or console.log the text - this will automatically create a simple embed with your text as the description:
```"Hello world!" // This creates a simple embed automatically```
```console.log("Debug message") // This also creates a simple embed```

tabs.name: Basic Embeds
content: Send embeds with basic properties:

tabs.name: Advanced Embeds
content: Create complex embeds with fields, author, and footer:

```sendMessage({
  title: "Advanced Embed",
  url: "https://example.com",
  description: "This embed has many features",
  author: ["Bot Name", "https://wynem.com/assets/images/logo/logo.webp", "https://example.com"],
  footer: ["Footer text", "https://wynem.com/assets/images/logo/logo.webp"],
  fields: [
    ["Field 1", "Value 1", true],
    ["Field 2", "Value 2", true],
    ["Field 3", "This field spans the full width", false]
  ],
  thumbnail: "https://wynem.com/assets/images/logo/logo.webp",
  image: "https://wynem.com/assets/images/logo/logo.webp",
  color: "#00ff00",
  timestamp: new Date()
})```

data.title: Advanced Embed
author: Bot Name
/assets/images/logo/logo.webp
https://example.com
fields: This field spans the full width

content: Author, footer, and fields also support object format:
**Multiple messages:** You can call `sendMessage()` multiple times, but it will edit the existing message with the updated content rather than sending separate messages.

**Important for eval command:** The eval command always returns the output. If you're using `sendMessage()` in eval, make sure to return `undefined` to prevent the message from being edited with the return value:

```sendMessage("Hello!")
return undefined // Prevents eval from editing the message```
Custom commands and auto-responses don't have this issue - they ignore the return value if you send a message.

tabs.name: Errors
content: The `sendError()` function is specifically designed for error messages. It automatically sets the author to "Error" with an error icon and uses a red color scheme.
**Simple error message:**
```sendError("Something went wrong!")```
**Error with title:**
**Error with additional fields:**

author: Error
/assets/images/emojis/error.webp
data.title: Command Failed
data.description: The command could not be executed

content: **Important notes about sendError():**

rows: Automatically set to "Error" with the <:error:> icon
Automatically set to `#DD2E44` (red) - cannot be overridden
If you pass a string, it becomes the embed description
If you set a `content` property in an object, it will be moved to the description
Plain text content (without embeds) is not supported - everything becomes an embed

tabs.name: Members
content: Your custom code can retrieve member and user information using the `getMember()` and `getUser()` functions.
The `getMember()` function retrieves server member information and accepts user IDs, member names, nicknames, and special shortcuts:
**Shortcuts for getMember():**

rows: Target the member from the previous message
Target your user (will not include server-specific data like nickname and server avatar)

content: The `getUser()` function retrieves basic Discord user information using only user IDs:

```const user = await getUser("737080713181921361")
const user2 = await getUser(member.id)```
**Key differences:**

`getMember()` returns the complete member object, which includes roles, permissions, server profile data, and also contains the user object. `getUser()` only returns basic Discord user data. Use `getUser()` when you only need basic user information or when the user might not be in the current server.

tabs.name: Bans
content: Your custom code can manage server bans using the `banUser()` and `unbanUser()` functions. These functions include automatic permission validation and error handling.
Provide the user's Discord ID as a string:
```banUser(user.id)```
**Ban with reason and message deletion:**
Provide the user's Discord ID as a string:
```unbanUser("737080713181921361", "Appeal accepted")```

tabs.name: Kicks
content: Your custom code can kick members from the server using the `kickMember()` function. This function includes automatic permission validation and error handling.
Provide the user's Discord ID as a string:
```kickMember(user.id)```
**Kick with reason:**
```kickMember("737080713181921361", "Spamming in chat")```

tabs.name: Timeouts
content: Your custom code can timeout members using the `timeoutMember()` function. This function includes automatic permission validation and error handling.
Provide the user's Discord ID and timeout duration in milliseconds:
```timeoutMember(user.id, 3600000) // 1 hour```
**Timeout with reason:**
```timeoutMember("737080713181921361", 600000, "Breaking server rules") // 10 minutes```
**Remove timeout:**
```timeoutMember("737080713181921361", 0) // Removes timeout```
**Timeout durations:**

description: For API actions to work, both the bot and the user executing the code must have the required permissions for that action.
When code is triggered automatically (such as through auto-responses), permissions are checked against the person who originally configured the feature instead of the user who triggered it.
Custom code has certain limitations for security and performance:

rows: Limited to 5 API calls (like sendMessage) per execution

description: **Basic greeting with user mention:**````Hello ${user.username}! Welcome to ${guild.name}`â€‹```

**Random response:**```const responses = ["Yes!", "No!", "Maybe...", "Ask again later"]
const random = responses[Math.floor(Math.random() * responses.length)]
return random```

**Complex embed with user info:**```sendMessage({
  title: "User Information",
  description: `Information about ${user.username}`,
  fields: [
    ["User ID", user.id, true],
    ["Joined Discord", new Date(user.createdTimestamp).toLocaleDateString(), true],
    ["In Server Since", member ? new Date(member.joinedTimestamp).toLocaleDateString() : "N/A", true]
  ],
  thumbnail: user.displayAvatarURL,
  colour: "#00ff00"
})```

rows: Test your code thoroughly before implementing complex logic
When testing, output debugging information - it will be shown in the response
You can use both JavaScript and TypeScript syntax
Always handle errors gracefully - if your code throws an error, it will be displayed to the user
